message.body: What is the favorite place you have ever lived and why?
My apartment, because I'm not living with my family and there are still trees around.
not living with my family or other people who I had little to no choice of
I meant more like geographically
I get the impression that you're not too keen on moving :\
Enh, I do what I have to
Already put my application in at a complex in Norristown
Have you considered renting a house instead of an apartment?
Yes, but I prefer dealing with established management and not landlords, based on my previous experience. And apartments have more leniency regarding holding and move-in dates.
And they have pools. =|
there are pros and cons, generally I have preferred living in houses than in apartments
/shrug it's more or less the same to me
Apartment living is 'simpler' for the most part. If you can find a nice complex w/ washer/dryer in unit that is a plus
Yeah, it does
and the rent is reasonable?
2 br/2 bath, upgraded kitchen, W/D + laundry room, 22' balcony for $1167/mo
+ fitness center and pool
I mean, the weights part of the fitness center suck, but the cardio equipment isn't bad
that doesnt sound bad, but you said its in norristown?
East Norriton
ohhhh
Germantown & 202 pretty much
hmmm, I wonder if ive been there before
nope, doesnt ring a bell
Well you clearly like the complex enough to put in an app, but you certainly don't seem overly thrilled about moving...or is it just the roommate situation
I dislike moving, and I'm not entirely enamored of the complex
It looks like a creepy hotel from the outside
The apartment itself is nice enough, I guess
I got spoiled living in Florida
well Halloween is coming up
Where complexes and landlords actually have to compete
so you liked living in FL better
Only the complexes themselves
I like having my coaxial cables run through the walls, not under the carpet, for example
have you looked at any other places?
Or having ethernet wiring at all
Yes, I have thoroughly searched the entire area
Through multiple means
To identify any and all apartment complexes
I follow
there's one other one that I could check, but their website blows, their staff don't respond to emails, and it's right in KoP
maybe you should consider a house, I saw some that looked promising the other week
I like living country-ish
This apartment complex also only requires a $200 security deposit
yeah, most houses want a months rent as security
but you get it back
I like the privacy of having a house, plus no parking lot and stairs and all that
Yeah. When I get enough money to buy, it will be a house--not a condo or a townhouse. But right now I don't particularly care.
Apartment is easier and cheaper, and I'll deal with the weird things.
I can paint the apartment though
there is much to be said for not caring
Which will be nice, if I actually bother to do so
word of advice, do it before you move in, or it will never happen
Yeah
I'm going to end up overlapping the month of October
So I'll have time to do it
O.o
Yeah, it's nice when you can take your time moving
happy friday elf
has anyone figured out the average cost of raising a child in the U.S.?
I'm sure they have
And hello
http://www.google.com/search?q=cost+of+raising+a+child&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=org.mozilla:en-US:official&client=firefox-a
problem is, you can raise a child on next to nothing, especially if you take advantage of the welfare programs. But what if you pay child support and what not?
Depends on the settlement, I imagine.
I think they base it on a percentage though
http://moneycentral.msn.com/content/collegeandfamily/raisekids/p37245.asp
Housing?
It's hard to see how you can justify adding housing for each age bracket
Presumably it's mostly a one-time expense, barring utility usage
I guess property taxes
But still.
yeah, I mean you still have to live somewhere, even if you dont have kids.
I feel in most cases an extra 100-150 sqft of space equates to 2.5-3k/year
will not equate to*
hmm, actually thats not that far off
thing is, I don't get a rebate on my mortgage because Im not currently using that 150 sf for my kid

"It also doesn't consider lost income that occurs when one parent decides to stop working or take off several years to raise their children during the early years -- or take a lesser-paying job with more predictable hours. That's money out of your pocket."
